title: Marabou (fashion)
text:
Marabou (historically spelled marabout) describes a certain type of <a href="down%20feather">down feather</a> trimming. Although it takes its name from the <a href="marabou%20stork">marabou stork</a> whose undertail down once provided the feathers, white <a href="domesticated%20turkey">turkey</a> feathers have been used as a substitute. The advantage of marabou is that it takes dye well, making it a very versatile trimming for dress, and makes an effective substitute for fur. While marabou has been widely used as a fashion trimming since the late 19th century, it is also often used in <a href="fly%20tying">fly tying</a> for making up the <a href="artificial%20fly">lures ('flies')</a> used for <a href="fly%20fishing">fly fishing</a>.
In fashion.
"Marabout" was a very popular trimming from the late eighteenth century onwards. It was used for trimming hats and making up <a href="muff%20%28handwarmer%29">muffs</a> and <a href="feather%20boa">feather boa</a>s. <a href="The%20Great%20Exhibition">The Great Exhibition</a> of 1851 prominently featured marabout alongside other feathers as second only in popularity to <a href="ostrich">ostrich</a> feathers, and it was noted that white marabout was sometimes very scarce, and also that some manufacturers were making highly commended items from turkey and goose-down.
Since the 20th century, marabou (spelt without a T) has become associated with lingerie and sex appeal. The <a href="Metropolitan%20Museum">Metropolitan Museum</a> states that 'no object better epitomizes the <a href="sex%20kitten">sex kitten</a> glamour of the 1950s than the marabou <a href="mule%20%28shoe%29">mule</a>.' Marabou mules are popularly associated with glamorous 1950s actresses such as <a href="Marilyn%20Monroe">Marilyn Monroe</a>, who wore them in "<a href="The%20Seven%20Year%20Itch">The Seven Year Itch</a>".
